awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engaging High School Students in Computer Science with Co-creative Learning Companions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates how state-of-the-art creative and pedagogical agents can improve students' learning, attitudes, and engagement with computer science. The project will be conducted in high school classrooms using EarSketch, an online computer science learning environments that engages over 160,000 learners worldwide in making music with JavaScript or Python code. The researchers will build the first co-creative learning companion, Cai, that will scaffold students with pedagogical strategies that include making use of learner code to illustrate abstraction and modularity, suggesting new code to scaffold new concepts, providing help and hints, and explaining its decisions. This work will directly address the national need to develop computing literacy as a core STEM skill.

The proposed work brings together an experienced interdisciplinary team to investigate the hypothesis that adding a co-creative learning companion to an expressive computer science learning environment will improve students' computer science learning (as measured by code sophistication and concept knowledge), positive attitudes towards computing (self-efficacy and motivation), and engagement (focused attention and involvement during learning). The iterative design and development of the co-creative learning companion will be based on studies of human collaboration in EarSketch classrooms, the findings in the co-creative literature and virtual agents research, and the researchers' observations of EarSketch use in classrooms. This work will address the following research questions: 1) What are the foundational pedagogical moves that a co-creative learning companion for expressive programming should perform?; 2) What educational strategies for a co-creative learning companion most effectively scaffold learning, favorable attitudes toward computing, and engagement?; and 3) In what ways does a co-creative learning companion in EarSketch increase computer science learning, engagement, and positive attitudes toward computer science when deployed within the sociocultural context of a high school classroom? The proposed research has the potential to transform our understanding of how to support student learning in and broaden participation through expressive computing environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funded research explored the design, development, and assessment of the world’s first co-creative intelligent learning companion for learning domains that mix technical knowledge (like programming or engineering) with expressive skills (like music making, story writing, or visual art).  We built a co-creative AI (called CAI) to be used within the EarSketch learning environment, an online computer science learning environment where students express themselves via making music with Python or JavaScript and controlling musical beats, samples, and effects with code. We explored how to use approaches from intelligent tutoring, machine information retrieval, and human-centered AI to design an AI that could act like a “slightly more knowledgeable peer” for high school CS learners.  We worked with high school teachers and their classrooms in Georgia, Illinois, and Florida to co-design and assess an initial CAI prototype in their computer science high school classes.  Our initial research yielded a better understanding of how student learners collaborate in their classrooms to inform how we designed our AI.  Our findings in evaluating our CAI prototype were mixed: while we found no significant quantitative results between “using CAI” to “not using CAI” with EarSketch, our qualitative results yielded a significantly richer understanding of how to build co-creative AI for EarSketch and other expressive/technical applications.  CAI’s development also yielded a useful standalone component that is now being used in the EarSketch annual competition: the first automated creativity assessment tool for expressive/technical environments.

A major thrust of the early years of this work was investigating dialogues between pairs of human high school students as they co-created together. We analyzed the pairs’ dialogues and their actions within EarSketch using an AI approach (hidden Markov model), and we were able to identify three “states” related to dialogue and four “states” related to task actions. A typical flow of a co-creative sessions starts with students exchanging greetings (Social Dialogue state), then moves to students deciding what type of song they would like to make (Aesthetic Dialogue state), then discussing the technical implementation and tasks requirements (Technical Dialogue state), and finally moving through the four task related states as they implemented their plans, occasionally moving back into the Aesthetic or Technical Dialogue states when they needed to revise their approach. After learning this process, we uncovered which patterns were associated with how satisfied students were with their partner using a self-reported measure. For example, students were less satisfied with their partner when they spent a lot of time addressing coding errors or frequently moving from discussing creative ideas directly to discussing the technical implementation of these ideas. This research has implications for co-creative systems and how they support students as they move through the co-creative process.

The project has also advanced knowledge on how to design co-creative AI for learning. We designed CAI to encourage students’ creativity and mastery of the musical and coding concepts taught in the EarSketch curriculum. To this end, we built a recommendation system for the EarSketch sound library that suggests sounds to encourage diversity in the sounds used by learners. We also developed a code analysis system for CAI that determines the level of knowledge displayed of various coding techniques. This system measures the complexity of the code, as well as the structure and aesthetic properties of the music created by the code. This analysis tool was used in the grading of submissions for Your Voice is Power, an annual EarSketch competition sponsored by Amazon for middle & high schoolers. We additionally created a dialogue system for CAI that provides music and code-related suggestions for users. CAI’s dialogue is designed to advance a user’s understanding of concepts in the EarSketch curriculum through contextual sound recommendations, code explanations and examples, suggestions based on a user’s current actions and past projects, and demonstrations of the EarSketch interface.

Finally, the project has advanced automated creativity assessment. EarSketch–with its combination of programming and music making–provides a unique and valuable opportunity for automated, objective assessment of creativity. Students’ projects included various features that we harnessed for creativity assessment. We defined creativity as a) divergent thinking (fluency, flexibility, originality, and elaboration), b) the complexity of their projects (code and music complexity), and c) effort (time on task). We conducted a study and gathered data from 53 students’ music projects in EarSketch and then asked ten EarSketch experts (with more than five years of experience) to rate those projects for their creativity. Then, we correlated the average rating of the experts with our automated assessment of creativity and we found a strong correlation showing evidence for the validity of our automated creativity assessment. We will use this assessment to assess students’ creativity in real-time and provide support for them to enhance the creativity of their projects.
